results.title: (dis)LOCATIONs symposium
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Shaw, Dennis Del Favero, Peter Weibel and Anna Munster
results.brief_description:
A conference about fragmentation of ‘community’, urbanisation and the collapse of locale and neighbourhood, the erosion of the private spaces of the sexual and familial. These have emerged as thematics attributable to the restructuring and divergent flows of new information economies and mediascapes.

Featuring key note speakers including Jeffrey Shaw, Dennis Del Favero, Agnes Hegedus, Susan Norrie, Peter Weibel, Ursula Frohne, Lev Manovich.

results.title: #MorbiusSweep
results.material_description: Digital Screen Recording of @RickOpsYT's twitter feed
results.brief_description: MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This particular tweet is packed full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as Director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This tweet mixes well-known memes full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”, and satirically highlights how fandoms attempt to hijack critical responses by flooding Rotten Tomatoes with disingenuous reviews, laying bare the intersection between internet hype and movie success.
description_for_label: #MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This tweet mixes well-known memes full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”, and satirically highlights how fandoms attempt to hijack critical responses by flooding Rotten Tomatoes with disingenuous reviews, laying bare the intersection between internet hype and movie success.

results.title: "War Pictures": Australians at the Cinema 1914-1918
results.brief_description:
A compilation of archival films that chronicles the Australian cinema-going experience during WWI from 1914 to 1918.

Between 1914 and 1918, cinema attendance was on the rise and the local film industry was expanding with over 50 Australian feature films produced during the period. While many of these films have been tragically lost, those that remain offer a rare glimpse into Australian life during this turbulent time.

As the war began, filmmakers rushed to make features about Australia’s involvement. Alfred Rolfe’s ‘Hero of the Dardanelles’ (1915) told the story of Gallipoli, complete with landing scenes shot at Tamarama Beach in Sydney.

However, as the years progressed, war-weary audiences lost their taste for patriotic stories, and a new genre of home-grown comedies emerged featuring knockabout characters from the Australian bush. Throughout the war years, Hollywood dramas, serials, love stories and comedies were also staple attractions, and Charlie Chaplin was an international superstar.

War Pictures offers a wide-ranging selection of local and international material, including a focus on Australia’s ‘lost films’.

Specially commissioned introductions and musical accompaniment offer contemporary audiences a chance to step back time and experience cinema as it was enjoyed during the First World War.

This work was shown at ACMI from 10 March to 26 July 2015 in the ‘War Pictures’ exhibition.

results.title: !OINK
results.creator_credit: Ruth Fleishman and Victoria University EDIM
results.brief_description: An interactive adaptation of a novel by Melbourne writer Eric Dando, !OINK is an exploration through various stages of life of Squirly Fern. We travel into the details of his life as he tries to find a place for himself in a world of the post-human step family animal/human genetic engineering; alien prototype inventions; corporate ownership od sleep and awake states and technology as a spiritual saviour.

results.title: Russia crossing the Ukrainian border
results.brief_description: Russian President Vladimir Putin has ordered troops into the two Russian-controlled areas of Ukraine on “peacekeeping duties”. Western European leaders and the US continue to attempt to negotiate a peaceful outcome for Ukraine, but the presence of 190,000 Russian troops at the border is keeping the tension at boiling point. Is the Russian leader engaging in high-stakes political theatrics to prove a point to Nato, or is he going to take Ukraine and possibly other former USSR nations back under Russian control by force?

results.title: Friends of the Bendigo Botanical Gardens
results.brief_description: Bendigo is better known for its old historic buildings than its heritage listed Botanic Gardens. Jan Orr, Rodney Orr and Glenys Anthony, members of the Friends of the Bendigo Botanic Gardens, talk about the history and some of the features of the Conservatory Gardens, including the rose garden and the fernery. The aim of the “Friends” group is to promote, protect and restore Bendigo’s heritage listed gardens.
